title: R41822
content: The 112th Congress is considering legislative proposals to limit the government's risk from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two government-sponsored enterprises responsible for nearly half of the nation's outstanding residential mortgage debt. In 2008, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac faced capital inadequacy due to increased mortgage defaults and foreclosures, leading to the U.S. Department of the Treasury purchasing over $175 billion of special preferred stock to support the mortgage markets during the financial crisis. The U.S. Department of the Treasury purchased over $175 billion of special preferred stock to support Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac during the 2008 financial crisis. Treasury and the Federal Reserve also provided mortgage market support by purchasing nearly $1.4 trillion in MBS. Treasury's purchase of preferred stock includes contracts requiring the enterprises to pay a 10% cash dividend annually. The enterprises' survival without continued Treasury support is uncertain. The U.S. Department of the Treasury purchased over $175 billion in preferred stock to support Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac during the 2008 financial crisis. Legislation may reduce the enterprises' size and increase their cost of doing business, potentially leading to lower mortgage prices and higher interest rates for borrowers. One category of proposed legislation, such as H.R. 1222, would increase the cost of doing business for enterprises like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. This could result in lower mortgage prices and higher interest rates for borrowers. Another group of bills, like H.R. 1227, would impose new limitations on the types of mortgages the enterprises can purchase, allowing more competition in the market. Some bills, including H.R. 31 and H.R. 1225, aim to increase regulatory oversight and disclosure. The proposed legislative changes aim to increase regulatory oversight, disclosure, and capital requirements for enterprises like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Additionally, there are proposals to limit the types of mortgages they can purchase, set deadlines for returning to stockholder control, and require filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The SEC would eliminate a competitive advantage for enterprises like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, requiring them to follow the same rules as competitors. Legislative proposals include setting deadlines for returning to stockholder control or dissolution, phasing out charters, and replacing the enterprises in secondary mortgage markets. In the 112th Congress, legislative proposals were introduced to address the financial difficulties of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, including setting deadlines for returning to stockholder control or dissolution and replacing the enterprises in the secondary mortgage markets. In September 2008, both enterprises entered voluntary conservatorship under the Federal Housing Finance Agency. In September 2008, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac entered voluntary conservatorship under the Federal Housing Finance Agency, with the Treasury providing financial support to keep them solvent. Homeowners and potential homeowners indirectly rely on them for mortgage money. The enterprises purchase mortgages from lenders, package them into MBS, and either keep them in portfolio or sell them. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac purchase mortgages from lenders and package them into MBS, providing a guarantee for repayment. They back almost half of the nation's home mortgages. The Obama Administration's report presents three alternatives for the future of the enterprises and the housing finance system. The Obama Administration's report outlines three alternatives for the future of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which back almost half of the nation's home mortgages. These alternatives include a privatized system with government mortgage programs targeted towards specific groups, a privatized system with government guarantee only during crises, and a privatized system with government reinsurance of private mortgage insurance. No legislation has been introduced to implement these alternatives yet. Most bills focus on specific areas like executive compensation, while some companion bills aim to reform multiple areas. One bill, H.R. 31, the Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Accountability and Transparency for Taxpayers Act of 2011, would require the director to make changes to the enterprises' operations. H.R. 31, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Accountability and Transparency for Taxpayers Act of 2011, would require the director of FHFA to make quarterly reports on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in 12 specific areas, including total liabilities, executive compensation, foreclosure mitigation efforts, and mortgage fraud prevention efforts. The director of FHFA is required to report quarterly on various aspects of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, including executive compensation, reducing loan limits, foreclosure mitigation, mortgage fraud prevention, communications with Federal Reserve and Treasury, enterprise investments, equity investments by Treasury, capital levels, underwriting standards, mortgage buyback policies, and actions affecting enterprise securities. The FHFA director must report quarterly on various aspects of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, including executive compensation, reducing loan limits, foreclosure mitigation, mortgage fraud prevention, and enterprise investments. The reports must also cover underwriting standards, mortgage buyback policies, and actions affecting enterprise securities, with additional relevant information as deemed necessary. The FHFA inspector general will review the reports and inform Congress of findings, with all information to be posted on the FHFA website. Additionally, the IG will examine FHFA's loss mitigation policies. The bill requires the FHFA inspector general to review reports on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, including loss mitigation policies and the impact of principal reduction on financial condition. The IG's findings will be shared with Congress and posted on the FHFA website, with some overlap in reporting requirements with current reports. The FHFA's reports cover capital, investments, loss mitigation activities, and the impact of reducing the conforming loan limit. Legislation requires the FHFA inspector general to review reports on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, including loss mitigation policies and principal reduction impact on financial condition. Findings will be shared with Congress and posted on the FHFA website. The Committee on Financial Services marked up H.R. 31 and sent it to the full committee. H.R. 1223, GSE Credit Risk Equitable Treatment Act of 2011, aims to prevent discrimination against mortgage-backed securities issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. It requires regulatory determinations on low-risk mortgages to not solely consider the enterprises' role in securitization. This is in line with Dodd-Frank regulations. The Dodd-Frank Act requires joint regulations to implement risk retention requirements for mortgages in MBS, with QRMs exempt. The Federal Reserve's general counsel testified that the enterprises' guarantees do not satisfy the risk retention requirements of the proposed rules. The enterprises' guarantees of timely payment on their MBS may not satisfy risk retention rules, but could be allowed if they are in conservatorship or receivership. The Act of 2011 requires Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to reduce their portfolios to $250 billion each over five years. The financial support agreements with Treasury mandate a gradual decrease in mortgage portfolios, reaching $250 billion in 2022. H.R. 2462, Cap the GSE Bailout Act of 2011, sets the maximum amount of support Treasury has contracted to provide each enterprise in the Preferred Stock Purchase Agreements (PSPA). The bill allows for additional financial support if the private secondary mortgage market is not viable. Initially, the limit was $100 billion for each GSE, but it was raised to $200 billion each. The Treasury has contracted to purchase preferred stock to keep the enterprises solvent, with limits initially set at $100 billion for each GSE, later raised to $200 billion each. The PSPA were amended to provide unlimited support in 2010-2012, with $200 billion limits outside of those years. H.R. 2413, Secondary Market Facility for Residential Mortgages Act of 2011, would create a federal corporation to purchase and securitize mortgages meeting underwriting standards, charging guarantee and reinsurance fees. The proposed federal corporation would purchase and securitize mortgages meeting underwriting standards, charging guarantee and reinsurance fees. The fees would be adjusted to maintain market share under 50%, with the goal of covering mortgage payments during normal times and compensating Treasury for the federal guarantee. Fees would be based on mortgage quality, regardless of location, volume, or homeowner cost reductions. The reinsurance fee would compensate Treasury for the federal guarantee, based on mortgage quality. Mortgages eligible for purchase would be for 30 years or less, up to 80% of the sales price (or 90% with seller participation or private mortgage insurance). FHFA would oversee the facility.
